questions.question: What does CCNA stand for?
questions.explanation: CCNA stands for Cisco Certified Network Associate, which is an entry-level certification for IT networking professionals.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a private IP address range?
questions.explanation: 192.0.2.0/24 is part of the TEST-NET range reserved for documentation and examples, not for private use.

questions.question: What OSI layer is responsible for logical addressing and routing?
questions.explanation: Layer 3 (Network) of the OSI model handles logical addressing (IP addresses) and routing between networks.

questions.question: Which protocol is used to automatically assign IP addresses to devices on a network?
questions.explanation: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) is used to automatically assign IP addresses and other network configuration parameters to devices.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a VLAN?
questions.explanation: VLANs (Virtual Local Area Networks) are used to logically segment a network into different broadcast domains, improving security and performance.

questions.question: Which protocol is used to convert domain names to IP addresses?
questions.explanation: DNS (Domain Name System) is used to translate human-readable domain names into IP addresses that computers can understand.

questions.question: What is the maximum transmission unit (MTU) of a standard Ethernet frame?
questions.explanation: The standard MTU for Ethernet is 1500 bytes, which is the maximum size of the data payload.

questions.question: Which routing protocol uses the Dijkstra algorithm to calculate the shortest path?
questions.explanation: OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) uses the Dijkstra algorithm to calculate the shortest path to each destination.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Spanning Tree Protocol (STP)?
questions.explanation: STP prevents switching loops in networks with redundant paths by blocking certain ports to ensure only one active path exists.

questions.question: Which of the following is a link-state routing protocol?
questions.explanation: OSPF is a link-state routing protocol that maintains a complete map of the network topology and calculates the shortest path to each destination.
